task.title: Emergency Repairs
task.shortdesc: Basic procedures for handling common roadside emergencies.

ul.li: Move vehicle to a safe location away from traffic if possible
Turn on hazard lights to alert other drivers
Set up warning triangles or flares if available and safe to do so
Assess whether it's safer to call for professional roadside assistance

context.p: Knowing how to handle common vehicle emergencies can help you get back on the road safely or prevent further damage while waiting for professional assistance. These procedures cover the most frequent roadside emergencies drivers encounter.

ol.li: Park on a flat, stable surface away from traffic
Apply parking brake and put automatic transmissions in Park or manual transmissions in gear
Place wheel chocks (or rocks/wood blocks) on the opposite side of the flat tire
Remove spare tire and tools from storage area
Remove any wheel cover or hubcap to access lug nuts
Use lug wrench to turn lug nuts counterclockwise to loosen (but don't remove yet)
Apply downward pressure on wrench and use body weight if necessary
Locate proper jacking point (solid frame member) near the flat tire
Position jack under jacking point (consult owner's manual for exact location)
Raise vehicle until flat tire is approximately 6 inches off the ground

step.cmd: Remove flat tire and install spare

ol.li: Remove lug nuts completely and place in secure location
Remove flat tire by pulling straight toward you
Lift spare tire into position, aligning holes with wheel studs
Install lug nuts and hand-tighten in a star pattern
Lower vehicle until spare tire contacts the ground but still bears no weight
Tighten lug nuts in a star pattern (opposite sides, not in circle)
Lower vehicle completely and remove jack
Fully tighten lug nuts to proper torque if possible
Position working vehicle close to disabled vehicle but ensure vehicles are not touching
Turn off ignition in both vehicles
Turn off lights, radio, and other electrical accessories
Open hoods and locate batteries
Identify positive (+) and negative (-) terminals on both batteries

step.cmd: Connect jumper cables in proper sequence

ol.li: Connect red clamp to positive (+) terminal of dead battery
Connect other red clamp to positive (+) terminal of good battery
Connect black clamp to negative (-) terminal of good battery
Connect other black clamp to unpainted metal surface on disabled vehicle's engine (NOT to negative terminal of dead battery)
Start the working vehicle and run for 2-3 minutes
Start the disabled vehicle (if it doesn't start, check connections and try again)
Once disabled vehicle starts, remove jumper cables in reverse order of connection
Keep the jumped vehicle running for at least 20 minutes to recharge battery

step.cmd: Respond to initial signs of overheating

ol.li: Watch for temperature gauge in red zone or warning light
Turn off air conditioning and turn on heater to maximum (draws heat from engine)
If in traffic, shift to neutral at stops and gently rev engine to increase coolant circulation
Pull over to safe location away from traffic
Turn off engine
Open hood (use caution - release latch from inside vehicle first)
Allow engine to cool for at least 30 minutes
Wait until engine is cool before removing radiator cap or coolant reservoir cap
Use thick cloth or gloves to protect hands
Slowly turn cap counterclockwise to first stop to release pressure before fully removing
Check coolant level and add if low (use 50/50 mix of coolant and water or plain water in emergency)
Look for disconnected hoses, broken belts, or visible leaks
Check radiator for blockage (leaves, debris, etc.)
If major leak is found, professional repair is likely needed

result.p: These emergency repair procedures can help you address common roadside problems and either resume your journey or safely await professional assistance.

ul.li: Have the vehicle inspected by a professional as soon as possible
Replace temporary spare tires promptly (not designed for extended use)
Recharge or replace battery if it needed jump starting
Replenish emergency supplies used during the repair
